column2: there are two passions which have a powerful influence on the affairs of men. These are ambition and avarice; the love of power
column3: and the love of money. Separately each of these has great force in prompting men to action; but when united in view of the same object
column4: they have in many minds the most violent effects. Place before the eyes of such men
column5: a post of honour that shall be at the same time a place of profit
column6: and they will move heaven and earth to obtain it. The vast number of such places it is that renders the British Government so tempestuous.Benjamin Franklin
column7: as recorded in James Madison‚Äôs notes on the Constitutional Convention

column1: theliberaltony 162800019949 "2017-07-09 22:45:06 GMT" http://theliberaltony.tumblr.com/post/162800019949/thebestpersonherelovesbucky-noseforahtwo "thebestpersonherelovesbucky:  noseforahtwo:  thebaconsandwichofregret:  kedreeva:  noseforahtwo:  As a chick married to an ex-cop
column2: I say this all the time to people close to me
column3: but it bears repeating here: No cop is your friend after you‚Äôve been detained. Get rear ended by a drunk at a red light? That cop will direct traffic around your vehicle
column5: sure. Call animal control on your piece of shit neighbor? You‚Äôve got a pretty good chance the officer who shows up helps out in a meaningful way. But after you‚Äôve been arrested
column7: ‚ÄúJust be honest with me and I‚Äôll do the same.‚Äù or the old ‚ÄúHelp me and I‚Äôll help you.‚Äù Politely ask for a lawyer. Shake your head. Ignore them. Pretend you‚Äôre Hollywood royalty being asked for a selfie. ‚Äú ‚Ä¶mmmm‚Ä¶ Sorry
column8: but no.‚Äù Keep your mouth shut. Don‚Äôt do their work for them. Wait for a lawyer.  I worked as a police dispatcher for a year and a half
column9: and I‚Äôd agree with this. My cops were generally nice people (and I say this having been on the wrong end of their sirens twice
column10: once before and once after being hired)
column11: and they often helped in good ways‚Ä¶ on the street. Not so much in the station. Generally speaking (and I know this is oversimplification and is worse in a lot of places but)
column12: it went like this:  On the street
column13: you were considered as a person/citizen they have sworn to protect who may have made a mistake or done something wrong. Once you were in the station
column14: you were considered as a criminal. In the station you are the only one on your side. Stay safe.  TV and film has you thinking that only guilty people ask for a lawyer. This is not true. The law is complex and difficult and confusing and if you‚Äôre being questioned by the police you‚Äôre not going to be in your best state of mind. A lawyer is your basic civil right and you should exercise that right. Keep silent
column16: take your legal advice. Guilty people don‚Äôt ask for a lawyer
column17: smart people do.  ‚ÄúGuilty people don‚Äôt ask for a lawyer
column18: smart people do.‚Äù  My uncle was a cop. My uncle is the most down to earth
column19: wouldn‚Äôt hurt a fly person in the world. I don‚Äôt think he even arrested a single person ever
column20: that wasn‚Äôt his job on the force. His advice? Get a fucking lawyer. Never say a damn word. A cop knows how to twist your words around and make you even doubt yourself. They know damn well how to make you feel guilty by getting a lawyer. YOU need to know that it‚Äôs SMART to get a lawyer. Get a lawyer.  " False text

column7: I was well educated. If you decide to sit

column10: such as wearing an armband or sitting for the pledge. They cannot force you to stand

column1: theliberaltony 162645948889 "2017-07-05 23:10:49 GMT" http://theliberaltony.tumblr.com/post/162645948889/glumshoe-glumshoe-i-cant-do-justice-to-one "glumshoe:  glumshoe:  I can‚Äôt do justice to one of the weirdest camp stories I know. My friend tells it so well
column2: and I can offer only a pale shadow of his story. Last summer
column3: he was working with one of the younger units comprised of ten year old boys. They had spent the night camping on another beach and were just readying themselves to depart. ‚ÄúMake sure you have all your things!‚Äù called my friend. ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt leave anything behind!‚Äù One small boy came up
column4: dragging a massive tangle of decomposing seaweed behind him. ‚ÄúBut‚Ä¶ what about me boy?‚Äù he asked
column5: lip trembling. ‚Äú‚Ä¶what is ‚Äòme boy‚Äô?‚Äù The child held up the stinking wad of bull kelp. ‚ÄúThis is him. This is Me Boy.‚Äù ‚ÄúMe Boy is not coming back with us
column6: ‚Äù said his counselor. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to leave Me Boy behind on the beach where he belongs.‚Äù The campers loudly mourned the loss of Me Boy. They insisted on giving him a Viking burial at sea
column7: which just consisted of pushing him solemnly off the back of the rowboat into the water and watching him drift away in the surf. That was only the beginning. Me Boy would be back. The campers
column9: possessed some kind of cultic hive-mind and a predisposition for bizarre memes. Me Boy would not be forgotten. They started telling each other stories about Me Boy and how he would one day rise again. There were warring factions with contradicting dogmas about Me Boy. Only when the gardener allowed them to take home a zucchini she had harvested did they find their god
column11: The Zucchini That Was A God
column12: became the whole unit‚Äôs mascot. The kids would bicker over who got to carry him. They built nests and carriers for Me Boy and brought him to different activities
column13: fiercely defending him from those that would do him harm. One child appointed himself the Voice of Me Boy and would translate the zucchini‚Äôs divine wishes into human speech.  It got out of hand. Me Boy had become a distraction
column15: a violent controversy. Something had to be done. My friend
column17: took it upon himself to kill Me Boy. The children wailed in despair as he chopped their God into refreshing slices. With this sudden turn of fortune
column18: followers of Me Boy turned to theophagy. ‚ÄúWe must eat him to preserve his power!‚Äù they cried. Boys who would otherwise never have touched a vegetable ate greedily of this sacrament
column19: eager to let Me Boy live on within them. For a time
column20: it seemed that peace and order had been restored
column21: and the religion had already faded into its silver age. But only for a time. In the last few days of camp
column22: the religion of Me Boy splintered into several denominations. Every meal yielded new vegetable matter said to be a reincarnation of Me Boy
column23: only for opposing groups to dismiss these as false prophets. Some believed that Me Boy was gone. Others believed his spirit lived on
column25: omnipresent. Some believed he had found a new vessel inside a carrot
column27: a slice of cantaloupe‚Ä¶ even inside a child. There was chaos
column29: and heartbreak without the guidance of Me Boy.  The tags on this post are very polarized. Half of them are¬†‚Äú#I‚Äôm glad I never went to camp‚Äù and¬†‚Äú#reasons why I never want kids‚Äù
column30: the other half are¬†‚Äú#BOY I LOVE CHILDREN CAMP IS SO GOOD AMIRIGHT?‚Äù " False text

column1: theliberaltony 162643375801 "2017-07-05 21:53:19 GMT" http://theliberaltony.tumblr.com/post/162643375801/afairlypudgycat-robotsandfrippary "afairlypudgycat:  robotsandfrippary:  stillstreetjoshua:  bpdzoldyck:  As someone who has been living with severe suicidal ideation my entire life I wanna tell you all something
column2: you don‚Äôt have to stay alive for yourself. People will say it‚Äôs a bad idea to live for external things because they‚Äôre temporary
column3: and it‚Äôs true living for yourself is ideal but if you‚Äôre not to that point yet that‚Äôs ok too.¬† I‚Äôve lived for my dog for the past 4 years
column4: before that I lived for my snakes
column5: before that I lived for my cat. You can live for whatever needs you and whatever matters to you. Live for your best friend
column8: live for your animal crossing town. Live for whatever keeps you alive and the day will come when you can live for yourself.  This is something everyone should see. Thank you for sharing this.  Transformers kept me alive.  When the 2007 movie was announced I was going through an incredibly hard time emotionally.  I saw the preview and every time I thought about killing myself I thought
column9: ‚Äúbut then I won‚Äôt get to see this thing I‚Äôve always wanted to see
column10: good or not.‚Äù  And it got me through.   I‚Äôm in a place where I live for myself now
column11: but don‚Äôt toss away a life preserver just because other people think you should be able to swim on your own.    don‚Äôt toss away a life preserver just because other people think you should be able to swim on your own   " False text

column1: theliberaltony 162588629094 "2017-07-04 13:00:27 GMT" http://theliberaltony.tumblr.com/post/162588629094/bringing-us-elections-into-the-21st-century-part "We have an outdated electoral system
column2: one that was set up in the 1700‚Ä≤s to support a small segment of the population in 13 Former Colonies.¬†We now reside in 50 states
column3: spanning 5 time zones and have the third largest population in the world.¬†It is time we make some steps to improve our electoral system. One of the first steps we should take is nationalizing elections. This will take the power to write election rules away from the states
column4: But this needs to be done a highly specific way
column6: so that the rules for elections cannot be changed easily. It should be a unified system
column7: meant to work perfectly for the purpose of time for elections.First
column8: I think a Top Two Primary system would be a great step in the right direction¬†It would allow each district to chose who the best two representatives wfor them would be then decied between those two to represent them in public office. It would end the strangle hold of the two party system and allow third parties to thrive.¬†All primaries should be held on July 4th
column9: which would become a paid holiday for all Americans.Because on this day
column10: we declared our Independence from Great Britain
column12: deriving their just powers from the consent of the governed (x)There would be no better day to vote.This would also be the set day for all special elections
column13: meaning that politicians cannot bury an election when few will be able to make it to the polls in order to maintain their power.¬†Finally
column14: Election Day would become a Paid National Holiday
column15: we could celibrate our democracy and vote.We could have the standard trappings of an American holiday
column17: in order to proclaim the power of the vote." True text

column2: Kamala Harris
column3: Kirsten Gillibrand
column5: and practically everyone else under the sun as potential Democratic presidential contenders
column6: most of the political class is ignoring the elephant in the room. Bernie Sanders is
column7: by some measures the most popular politician in America
column8: by far Democrats‚Äô most in-demand public speaker
column9: and the most prolific grassroots fundraiser in American history.If he were 10 or 20 years younger
column10: his absence from a 2020 cattle call held by the Center for American Progress back in May would have been glaring. As things stood
column11: the whisper among everyone in the halls was simply that he‚Äôs too old and obviously won‚Äôt run.But make no mistake: Sanders is the real 2020 Democratic frontrunner.He‚Äôs doing exactly what a candidate who fell short needs to do to run a second time. He‚Äôs established a national political organization
column12: he‚Äôs improved his ties with colleagues on Capitol Hill
column13: he‚Äôs maintained a heavy presence in national media
column14: and he‚Äôs traveling the country talking about issues.In subtle ways he‚Äôs shifted his policy commitments to the center
column15: making himself a more broadly acceptable figure in the party. At the same time
column16: he‚Äôs held on to a couple of signature issues ‚Äî Medicare-for-all and tuition-free public college ‚Äî that give him exactly the kind of clear-cut and broadly accessible agenda that mainstream Democrats lack.Of course
column17: if he were to run and win
column19: the oldest president on record by some margin. And maybe he won‚Äôt run. But his recent moves suggest that he is both interested in the nomination and very much the candidate to beat for it.Nobody thought Bernie Sanders could winBy the time it was clear the Sanders 2016 campaign had legs
column20: it was already fatally hobbled. Almost no one believed in the summer and fall of 2015 that he stood any chance of beating Hillary Clinton ‚Äî and that included Sanders himself. As Patrick Healy and Yamiche Alcindor reported last April
column21: he ‚Äúwas originally skeptical that he could beat Mrs. Clinton
column22: and his mission in 2015 was to spread his political message about a rigged America rather than do whatever it took to win the nomination‚Äù and only began to really focus on trying to win when his poll numbers unexpectedly soared in early 2016.Consequently
column23: labor leaders who sympathized with Sanders‚Äôs critique of Clinton didn‚Äôt give any serious thought to actually endorsing him. Instead
column24: they used his presence in the race as leverage to extract concessions on issues like the Trans-Pacific Partnership and the Cadillac tax on high-value health insurance plans from Clinton.And since Sanders was running to raise the profile of his issues rather than to win
column25: he didn‚Äôt bother to develop much in the way of answers to foreign policy questions
column26: even though Clinton‚Äôs record of support for the 2003 invasion of Iraq and her hawkish instincts were some of her biggest vulnerabilities with the Democratic Party base.Elected officials were almost uniformly afraid to endorse him
column27: even if their policy views were closer to his than to Clinton‚Äôs
column28: and left-of-center think tanks ‚Äî including ones that are deliberately positioned to the left of mainstream Democrats ideologically ‚Äî shied away from working with Sanders on policy development
column29: for fear that Clinton‚Äôs wrath would destroy them if they did.(Continue Reading)" False link
